columns.text:
In this exercise, if we are to receive $13,500 each year for the next five years with an interest of 6.8%, we will solve the following requirements:

- Identify the present value if the payment is in the form of an ordinary annuity and an annuity due.
- If we plan to invest the payment for five years, determine the future value if the payment is an ordinary annuity and an annuity due.
- Between the payment form of an ordinary annuity and an annuity due, which has the highest present and future value and why.

First, let's discuss the difference between an ordinary annuity and an annuity due.

The difference between an ordinary annuity and an annuity due is that in an annuity due payments are due at the beginning of the period, whereas, in an ordinary annuity, payment is due at the end of the period. Hence, these two forms of payments differ in calculating the present and future value.
A. For the first requirement, let's determine the present value of the annuity if it's in the form of an ordinary annuity and an annuity due.

In calculating the present value of the annuity, we will consider the following details from the problem:

| Particulars        |         |
|--------------------|---------|
| Constant payment | $13,500 |
| Interest rate      | 6.8%    |
| Period             | 5       |

The present value of an annuity refers to the current value of a series of fixed payments in the future, considering the interest rate and the annuity period.

The present value of an annuity in a form of an ordinary annuity can be calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Ordinary Annuity} &=C\times\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{\left(1+r\right)^t}}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$C$, which represent the constant payment\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Next, determine the present value of the annuity if the payment form is an annuity due.

To calculate the present value of an annuity if the payment form is annuity due, we will multiply the present value of the ordinary annuity by the factor of rate. Hence, we will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Annuity Due} &= \text{PV of Ordinary Annuity} \times \left(1+r\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$r$, which refers to the rate

Let's now calculate the present value of the annuity if the payment form is an annuity due.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Annuity Due} &= \$55,650.35 \times \left(1+0.068\right)
\\[5pt]
&= \$55,650.35 \times 1.068
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$59,434.57}
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, if the payment form is an annuity due, the present value of the annuity is $59,434.57.**
To summarize, if the payment form is an ordinary annuity, the present value of the annuity is $55,650.35 and $59,434.57 if the payment form is an annuity due.
B. For the following requirement, supposed we invest the 5-year annuity, we will determine the future value if the payment is an ordinary annuity and an annuity due.

In calculating the future value of the annuity, we will consider the following details:

| Particulars        |         |
|--------------------|---------|
| Constant payment | $13,500 |
| Interest rate      | 6.8%    |
| Period             | 5       |
The future value of an annuity refers to the value at a future date based on a series of fixed payments multiplied by the interest rate and the compounding period.

First, let's determine the future value of the investment annuity if the payment form is an ordinary annuity. We will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV of Oridnary  Annuity} &=C\times\dfrac{\left(1+r\right)^5-1}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which means the future value\
$C$, which represent the constant payment\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Next, identify the future value if the payment is an annuity due.

Suppose we invest the five-year annuity with a payment form of an annuity due. In that case, to determine the future value, we will multiply the future value of ordinary annuity by the rate factor. Therefore, the formula we will use is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV of Annuity Due} &= \text{FV of Ordinary Annuity} \times \left(1+r\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which means the future value\
$r$, which refers to the rate

Now, let's calculate the future value if the payment form is an annuity due.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV of Annuity Due} &= \$77,325.75 \times \left(1+0.068\right)
\\[5pt]
&= \$77,325.75 \times 1.068
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$82,583.90}
\end{aligned}$$

**Based on our calculation, if the payment form is an annuity due, the future value is $82,583.90.**
To summarize, if we invest in the 5-year annuity and the payment form is an ordinary annuity, the future value is $77,325.75. If the payment form is an annuity due, the future value is $82,583.90.
C. For the last requirement, we will discuss the highest present and future value between an ordinary annuity and annuity due, and it's always true.

In an ordinary annuity, the payment is made at the end of the period. On the other hand, the payment is made at the beginning of the period in an annuity due. For this reason, the interest will have more time to compound in an annuity due than in an ordinary annuity.

**Therefore, the annuity due will always both have the highest present value as well as the future value.**

To conclude, because of the compounding of interest, an annuity due payment form has a one-period advantage over the ordinary annuity since the payment is made at the beginning of each period. This is also why in our previous calculations, the present value and the future value of an annuity due are higher than the ordinary annuity calculations.
